div.p: got me a horse for the articles I have given him on his departure. "My son,["] said he "to morrow I am to Adopt one of the Shawyens for my Son, & to offer them a pipe, on which the Gros Ventres will put all their goods & the Shawyens their horses – according to our manner of trade we ought to expect at least 200 horses as we have that number of Guns besid other articles to put on the Pipe,– out of that number you can choose out a horse for yourself for you shall have the first choice[.]" If Mr C. was happy I was glorious to think that I was to choose a horse out of so many! I had been bargaining with a Shawyen for a fine Gray horse for Mr Henry – but he told me that the horse was to be put on the pipe of the G. Ventres[.] I consoled myself with the hopes that I would have for the Compy the horse that was refused to one of its members[.] Mr Henry said that if I was to get the horse for the Company that he would take him for himself & pay the Compy the goods I had given for the horse, or return me some goods to buy an inferior horse for the Compy, as the Compy did not want famous horses[.] I told him that he might take the horse provided he would pay 300 Livers for him the price that I could sell him for the Compy at the Red River – that I was bound to turn the goods given me in charge to the best advantage, & that it was indifferent to me to whom I sold them whether to a Proprietor[,] an engaged, or an Indian, provided they were equally good pay: Mr Henry said that he would take the horse in spite of me, being bought with the Company's property[.] Having said that I would put him or any other in defiance to take from me the least articles of the Compy, property while I did with it what was most necessary to be done, & that I acted there independant of him[.] Mr Henry told that I was very Pert, but Mr C. showed us the folly of quarreling for a thing that was
